bibl.title: Letter from George Miller Sternberg to Walter Reed, November 17, 1900

div1.p: Sternberg forwards Reed's paper for peer review. He agrees that the inoculation experiments must continue in order to provide scientific proof. He recommends that a search for the yellow fever parasite should begin.

div1.head: Letter from George Miller Sternberg to Walter Reed, November 17, 1900
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
Surgeon General's Office,
Washington, November 17, 1900.
Communications on official business should be addressed "To the Surgeon General, U.S. Army, Washington, D.C." Subject:
In reply refer to No.........
Major Walter Reed,
Surgeon, U. S. Army,
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba.
My dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I have just received your letter of November 13th.
I have sent reprints of your report to Professor Welch, Dr. Novey,
Dr. Archinard (New Orleans), Professor Roux (Pasteur Institute),
and to Dr. Adolpho Lutz (Brazil), and to the Editor of the Central-
blatt für Bacteriologie. I think it would be well for you to send
to all members of the Association of Physicians, as you suggest,
and the members of the Laboratory Committee of the Public Health
Association. I send you herewith a list of the special committees
which includes the names of all the more prominent members of the
Association.

I am glad to know that you are in a fair way to carry on
additional inoculation experiments. As I said to you when you were
in Washington, I consider this the most important matter for the
present. The profession generally will not be disposed to accept
the experiments already published as definitely settling the ques-
tion as to the role of the mosquito in the transmission of the
disease. When this is once settled beyond question, it will not
Major Walter Reed,- - - -p. 2.
be so essential that you should demonstrate the presence of the
parasite either in the blood of patients or in the bodies of
mosquitoes, although of course this will be extremely desirable
and is naturally the next step to be taken.

With kind regards to Dr. Carroll and to the medical offi-
cers of the Army on duty at Columbia Barracks, I remain,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, G.M. Sternberg
Surgeon General, U.S.Army (1 Enclosure)
